verses.text: When Nicanor heard that Judas and his companions were in the region of Samaria, he decided to attack them on the day of rest.
verses.comment: Nicanor plans to assault on the Sabbath, highlighting the Jewish observance and the enemy's disregard.

verses.text: When the Jews living in distress followed him in groups, he was forced to meet them in battle.
verses.comment: The Jews stand together against oppression, emphasizing unity amid trial (cf. Acts 4:32).

verses.text: But Nicanor, with disdain, sent messengers to Judas and his followers, saying, 'Surrender yourselves; you will receive mercy.'
verses.comment: The offer of mercy echoes how adversaries seek to persuade the faithful; a test of resolve.

verses.text: Judas replied, 'Heaven is our refuge; we will trust in Almighty God, who can deliver us from your assault.'
verses.comment: Judas's confidence in God recalls Old Testament faith, reflecting complete reliance on divine strength.

verses.text: Nicanor, angered by Judas’ words, ordered his troops to prepare for battle at once.
verses.comment: Hostility is intensified by the faith-driven response of the Jews, similar to Pharaoh's response to Moses (Ex 14:5).

verses.text: Then Nicanor declared, 'If Judas and his army are not delivered into my hands, I will burn this sacred temple.'
verses.comment: Threatening the sanctuary shows the enemy’s contempt for holy places and practices.

verses.text: But the priests, stretching out their hands toward heaven, prayed that God would defend and preserve the temple, which had been recently purified.
verses.comment: Priestly intercession for the sanctuary reflects trust in divine protection, drawing parallels to Aaron’s prayers (Num 16:48).

verses.text: Judas, urging his companions not to fear the enemy or their vast army, recalled how God had rescued them from many dangers before.
verses.comment: Assurance built on historical divine deliverance, a recurring biblical theme encouraging steadfast faith.

verses.text: He encouraged them with the words of the Law and the Prophets, reminding them of the battles they had already won.
verses.comment: Scripture is used for encouragement, reinforcing the authority and power of God’s word.

verses.text: By raising their spirits, he prepared them to stand firm and fight bravely, so that they would not fear the enemies but remember the injustices done to their nation.
verses.comment: Upholding justice and recalling past wrongs motivates righteous resistance; perseverance in faith.

verses.text: After equipping his forces, he joined with the seniors and, together, they pleaded for mercy and favor from God.
verses.comment: Appeal for mercy and guidance highlights collective prayer, reminiscent of communal intercession (Acts 1:14).

verses.text: In a dream, Judas saw Onias, the former high priest, a distinguished and virtuous man, his manner holy and majestic.
verses.comment: The vision underscores the reverence for the priesthood and spiritual leadership—dreams bear divine revelation.

verses.text: Onias stretched out his hands, praying for the entire Jewish community.
verses.comment: Again, emphasis on intercessory prayer, showing the deep spiritual connection within the body of believers.

verses.text: Then a majestic, elderly man appeared, dressed in wonderful splendor and glory.
verses.comment: Imagery aligns with descriptions of heavenly beings; reflection on glory points to spiritual realities.

verses.text: Onias said, 'This is Jeremiah, the prophet of God, who dearly loves the Jewish people.'
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s role as intercessor for Israel is recognized, reflecting respect for prophetic authority.

verses.text: Jeremiah extended his right hand, giving Judas a golden sword, and said,
verses.comment: The gift of the sword symbolizes divine empowerment for victory; connecting heavenly gifts and earthly action.

verses.text: 'Take this holy sword—a gift from God—by which you will defeat your enemies.'
verses.comment: The sword parallels New Testament imagery of the Word of God as a spiritual weapon.

verses.text: Awakened by the dream, having received this vision, Judas shared it with all, inspiring them for the battle.
verses.comment: The dream encourages faith, showing how God speaks to His people through visions (cf. Acts 10:9–16).

verses.text: Once, soon after, Judas’s men were still doubtful and afraid of the armies of Nicanor.
verses.comment: Fear is met by encouragement—human weakness balanced by God’s promises.

verses.text: Judas, seeing their fear, reminded them of the miracles God had performed in the past and of their present vision.
verses.comment: Remembrance of miracles strengthens faith; sets a pattern of relying on God’s provision.

verses.text: When all had been encouraged by his words, they prepared for battle, facing their enemies with courage.
verses.comment: Courage rooted in spiritual encouragement, a biblical principle found throughout redemptive history.

verses.text: Just at the moment of battle, Judas raised his hands toward heaven, praying:
verses.comment: Gesture of prayer underscores leadership dependent on God; mirrors Moses’s intercession (Ex 17:11).

verses.text: 'Lord, You sent Your angel under King Hezekiah and destroyed one hundred and eighty-five thousand soldiers of Sennacherib.'
verses.comment: Reference to miraculous deliverance, highlighting God’s intervention throughout history.

verses.text: 'Now also, Sovereign of the heavens, send a good angel ahead of us who will bring terror and dread to our enemies.'
verses.comment: Angelology: the ministry of angels in protection and victory—a theme deepened in Christian theology.

verses.text: With this prayer, Judas and his men swiftly advanced toward Nicanor.
verses.comment: Faith leads to action; confidence in God emboldens believers to confront opposition.

verses.text: But, being divinely supported, they brought down over nine thousand of Nicanor’s troops, wounded most, and forced the rest to flee.
verses.comment: Victory attributed to divine aid, not human strength—a foreshadowing of salvation by grace.

verses.text: Nicanor himself fell in battle, and they stripped him of his armor.
verses.comment: Defeat of the leader causes confusion for the enemy; reminiscent of David and Goliath.

verses.text: Raising shouts of praise, they returned, blessing the Lord who had preserved them.
verses.comment: Worship after victory reflects an attitude of gratitude, a repeated pattern in salvation history.

verses.text: They celebrated for thirty days, rejoicing with much gladness.
verses.comment: Extended celebration mirrors Old Testament feasts, fostering unity and remembrance.

verses.text: With Nicanor’s head and right hand displayed publicly near Jerusalem, they showed all the clear sign of the Lord’s assistance.
verses.comment: Physical signs underscore spiritual victory; outward symbols of God’s deliverance.

verses.text: Then the people decreed by unanimous decision never to let this day pass unobserved, but to celebrate it annually on the thirteenth of Adar.
verses.comment: Institution of a memorial day connects with tradition, remembrance, and communal liturgical practice.

verses.text: Thus, things worked out well with respect to Nicanor, and from then onward, the city remained at peace.
verses.comment: Peace as a divine gift—shaping the blessing of the people after faithful endurance.

verses.text: I, then, will end my account at this point.
verses.comment: The narrator’s conclusion invites reflection on God’s faithfulness throughout history.

verses.text: If what I have related is well written and arranged, that is what I desired; but if it is trivial and incomplete, that is all I could do.
verses.comment: Expressions of humility in writing, recognizing human limitation; reminiscent of Paul’s admission in 1 Cor 2:3.

verses.text: For just as it is harmful to drink only wine or only water, but pleasant to blend wine with water,
verses.comment: Metaphor of mixing suggests careful craftsmanship in writing and teaching; blending human effort with divine wisdom.

verses.text: So also the arrangement of the account brings delight to the listener.
verses.comment: Joy in the ordering of salvation history; testimony as a medium for spiritual edification.

verses.text: So now, this is the end.
verses.comment: The text closes, signaling completion and inviting the reader to consider what has been shared for personal growth.

verses.text: If things have been presented effectively, that is what I hoped; if not, please forgive me.
verses.comment: Acknowledges human weakness and appeals to the reader's mercy—mirroring the principle of grace.

verses.text: For just as it is harmful to drink wine alone or water alone, but delightful to combine them, so too the account meant to delight the attentive.
verses.comment: Another metaphor likening good storytelling to spiritual nourishment, subtly suggesting the value of Tradition along with Scripture for a richer faith.
